awd_titl_txt: Investigation of Boron and Boride Nanoclusters:  Laying the Foundation for New Boron Nanostructures and Nanomaterials
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanism (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Lai-Sheng Wang of Brown University and his students are using sophisticated laser spectroscopy techniques to study clusters of boron and metal borides. The clusters being studied are aggregates of 3-40 atoms.  The chemical and physical properties of these clusters depend on their size.   The Wang research group is able to continuously vary the number of atoms in a cluster, which means that they can explore in detail how the atoms are bonded to each other.  The chemical bonds in boron clusters are very strong, which might mean that these clusters may make possible new materials with new and useful properties. Prof. Wang and his research team are interested in creating and characterizing novel boron cluster structures including clusters containing a few metal atoms such as bismuth (Bi) cobalt (Co), rhodium (Rh), and iridium (Ir).  In addition to the lasers used in the experimental work, the Wang research team also do theoretical calculations that help interpret experimental data and predict new, never before seen structures (for example, what to clusters containing more than 50 atoms look like?). The long-term goal of the project is to discover new boron-based molecules and new forms of boron materials.

The project focuses on three sub-topics: 1) structural evolution of large size-selected boron clusters, 2) neutral boron clusters and borospherenes (cage-like boron clusters), and 3) metal-doped boron clusters. These clusters are produced by a laser-vaporization supersonic cluster source and studied by a variety of experimental and theoretical techniques. Photoelectron spectroscopy is used to probe the structures and bonding of large negatively-charged boron clusters with more than 40 atoms. High-resolution photoelectron imaging of negatively-charged boron clusters is employed to provide vibrational and structural information for the associated neutral clusters. An infrared and ultraviolet double-resonant approach is used to directly probe neutral boron clusters, as a complementary technique to the high-resolution photoelectron imaging experiment. The structures and bonding of metal-doped boron clusters are studied by both photoelectron spectroscopy and high-resolution photoelectron imaging. These experiments provide vibrational and electronic structure fingerprints, which are combined with computational chemistry to elucidate the structure, stability, and chemical bonding of boron and metal-doped boron clusters. The broader impact of this work is to build the foundation and knowledge base to discover new boron-based nanomaterials, which can have potential technological applications and societal benefits. This project is integrated to the teaching of physical chemistry by the PI, as well as providing research-training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research project was aimed at a fundamental understanding of boron and metal boride clusters, with the long-term goal of discovering new boron-based nanostructures and nanomaterials. The experiment involved photoelectron spectroscopy studies of size-selected cluster anions, produced by a laser vaporization supersonic cluster source. The objective of this project was to elucidate the structures and chemical bonding of boron and metal boride nanoclusters as a function of size, providing fundamental knowledge for new forms of boron nanostructures. A number of significant findings were made under this project. In prior funding period, the discovery of the planar B36 cluster with a hexagonal vacancy provided the first experimental evidence of stable atom-thin 2D boron with hexagonal vacancies and led to the coining of the name “borophene”, which have been synthesized experimentally and have become a new class of synthetic 2D nanomaterials. In the current funding period, it was found that the B48– cluster has a bilayer structure, suggesting the viability of bilayer borophenes. Major progresses were made in the area of metal boride clusters in this funding period. A series of di-lanthanide clusters, Ln2Bx– (x = 7–9) were found to form high symmetry inverse-sandwich type structures. Tri-lanthanide boride clusters, Ln3B18–, were found to have unprecedented cage structures, i.e., metallo-borospherenes.  

Transition metal doped boron clusters were another major focus of this project. Significant progresses were made for Re-doped boron clusters. While the ReB8– and ReB9– clusters were found to be Re-centered borometallic molecular wheels, the ReB6– cluster was found to be a boron analogue of metallabenzene. The most interesting finding was the ReB4– cluster, which has a pentagonal ring structure and was found to be Möbius-aromatic with 4 pi-electrons. Several breakthroughs were made in understanding the multiple bonding between boron and transition metal atoms. The most important discovery was the quadruple bond in the diatomic rhodium boride (Rh≣B). This discovery was highlighted in Chem & Eng News and the RhB diatomic molecule was named as one of the “molecules of the Year” in 2020 by Chem & Eng News. During this funding period, a major review article in Chemical Society Review was completed, reviewing the progress on the structures and bonding of size-selected boron and metal-boride clusters.

            This project allowed the support or partial support of six graduate students, three of whom have obtained their Ph.D. One of them is employed in industry and two are pursing postdoctoral research in academia. Two undergraduate students have participated in this project, one of the students won a 2021 Goldwater Scholarship. The PI has given numerous invited talks at international meetings and academic institutions, helping disseminate the research results from this project. The PI was also able to integrate research results from this project into the classroom in both introductory chemistry and physical chemistry. The project has created new knowledge of interdisciplinary interests, while simultaneously promoting teaching, training, and learning for both graduate and undergraduate students.
